description: Take a look into codecasting (programming) and some fundamental concepts:

content: To program means to give instructions to the computer, for example, play a certain sound, print something on the screen, or multiply two numbers.

When there is a series of commands, we have a computer program (script), it describes a sequence of calculations, evaluations, iterations, and all kinds of similar operations, which aim to accomplish some result.

The program is written in text format, which is called source code. It is written in a particular programming language. To write commands, we need to be familiar with the syntax and semantics of the language we'll be using, in our case - Java.
To print "Hello world", you can use the pre-defined Java command System.out.println(), to which you need to provide the text inside the parentheses that you'd like to be printed:

The above statement is pre-built into Java, and it's used for printing a string. The statement tells the computer to output the string that's been provided to it, placed between the quotation marks. The statement ends with a semicolon ;
The print command System.out.println("Hello world"); prints the text "Hello world."

You can print any text you want with the command, as long as the command System.out.println("text"); -i.e., System dot out dot println open parenthesis ( "the text" close parenthesis ) and semicolon ; remains unchanged.
The command below will print the text "Hello <username>!".
